deity.name: Asteran
deity.title: the First Twin
entries: Asteran and Zuriel were two angels, who both inhibited strong leader-like abilities. They were brought to divinity by Lumen, after he took notice of the twins. Asteran is now the only deity of angels, after Zuriel betrayed him, wounded him, and fell from divinity. Asteran is now leader over the angels and arch-angels of Xhoria. He rules over the angels from the Golden City of Alfhelas. Asteran himself is rarely seen as a patron, but his angels are.

deity.name: Auberon
deity.title: the Justicar
entries: Auberon was one of the two first telorin to exist on Xhoria, the other being Thena, his former wife. Stories tell of Auberon being a fair leader. Lumen took note of his extraordinary fairness and brought him up to divinity. He was wedded to Thena, but due to a terrible event between the two of them, Auberon abandoned Thena. Auberon is the deity over justice and nobility. Many lawyers and nobles have Auberon as their patron, and most telorin consider Auberon their main deity.

deity.name: Kagu
deity.title: the Whitesmith
entries: Kagu was one of the first blacksmiths in Xhoria, and also one of the best. He was touched by Lumen for his incredible talent and creativity, ascending him to divinity in the hopes of encouraging craftsmanship in Xhoria. He is now the god of creation and invention. Many craftsmen pray to Kagu to bless their work. He is the patron of blacksmiths, inventors and other craftsmen.

deity.name: Lumen
deity.title: the Burning Hand
entries: The Burning Hand, lord over the sun and fire, bringer of light and justice, is one of the two Prime Deities and head of the Deific Court. He is depicted as a humanoid figure, consisting of only light.

He was the first to battle against the Shadowbringer during The Dawn, making space for other divine beings to manifest a form. Commoners that are faithful to him are sometimes blessed with his divine energy, making it easier for them to grow crops, in power, or as a person.
He is often the patron to those that follow a similar righteous creed like the Hand himself.

deity.name: Lykor
deity.title: King of Frost
entries: Lykor is one of the two lords of nature. He is depicted as a white wolf. Many frost telorin worship Lykor for his relation to the cold weathers they are accustomed to.
As one of the first deities on Xhoria he created most of the nature Xhorians know. He also represents the lawful side of nature.
Many rangers and druids have Lykor as their patron.

deity.name: Namiza
deity.title: the Immortal Soul
deity.symbol: Side facing skull biting into a gem
entries: Namiza rejected the cycle of life and death when Zhizuna created the Weave, becoming the first lich of Xhoria. He was touched by Umbrava and became the deity of undeath. Namiza is one of the few who know the secrets of life and death, and many mages desire this knowledge.
He is depicted as a skull, encased in green and blue flames, representing his form after lichdom.
After ascending to Daemonhood, he became the patron of many necromancers.

deity.name: Norguul
deity.title: the Horned Rat
deity.symbol: The face of a horned rat
entries: Like Zotek, Norguul was one of the first skavarot on Xhoria. His main motivation was to bring the plague to everyone on Xhoria. Umbrava was impressed by his devotion to the plague, and gave him the opportunity to realize his desires. After being touched by Umbrava, Norguul became the Horned Rat, primary god of the skavarot. He is considered deity over illness and sickness.

deity.name: Septus
deity.title: the Devourer
entries: After Kagu became the deity of creation and invention, Umbrava sought out to create the Daemon perfect enough to counter Kagu. He shaped a blind black snake, like one of the Shadow Titans, and granted it divinity. This snake, Septus, is the deity of utter destruction and hunger. It does not usually have followers of any sanity, its followers have usually lost their mind, being deceived into its influence. Followers usually have taken out their eyes, to become like Septus and see with the boon Septus grants them.

deity.name: Sunari
deity.title: Queen of Warmth
entries: The Queen of Warmth is the second lord of nature. She is depicted as a yellow fox. Together with Lykor she forms the Monarchs of Nature.
She represents the chaotic side, but also the warmth, of nature.
Like the King of Frost she is patron to many rangers and druids.

deity.name: The All-Watcher
deity.symbol: Upside-down triangle with an eye in it
entries: The All-Watcher is a neutral deity, it is focussed on collecting knowledge. It is depicted as a giant eye, watching over Xhoria. Many worship it like a cult, but much is unknown about this deity.

deity.name: Thena
deity.title: the Melancholy Gloom
entries: Thena was one of the two first telorin to exist on Xhoria, the other being Auberon, her former husband. After Auberon abandoned her, a terrible depression overtook her. Umbrava took note of this event between Auberon and Thena, and given that Auberon was brought to divinity, he touched Thena and made her the deity of disorder and abandonment, a true embodiment of emotion and depression. Thena was thankful for the act of kindness Umbrava showed her. People that resonate with the events that Thena went through often pray to her for consolation.

deity.name: Umbrava
deity.title: the Shadowbringer
entries: The Shadowbringer, also known as the First Daemon on Xhoria or the head of the Daemons, is one of the two Prime Deities and lord of shadows and darkness. Depicted as a humanoid made of shadows with six dark tendrils as arms.
He was the original ruler over Xhoria during the Age of Dawn. During this time he created five Shadow Titans, of which the names have been lost to time.
He is the patron to the unfortunate warlocks or the many cultists that follow the shadows.

deity.name: Zotek
deity.title: the Mutator
entries: Zotek was the first kroxelhua in Xhoria, his thick black scales and enormous body did not go unnoticed by Umbrava. After Lumen touched Lykor, Umbrava retaliated by ascending Zotek to divinity, making him the destructive force of nature on Xhoria. Zotek is responsible for the monstrosities in Xhoria.
He is the patron of most Coatl in Xhoria, who see him as the one and only deity.

deity.name: Zhizuna
deity.title: the Web-Weaver
deity.symbol: Spider with a cross on its back
entries: Zhizuna is the deity over the afterlife. Depicted as a spider with a green glowing cross on its back.

She is ruler over the Weave, the large web of life and death that spans over the Xhorian Multiverse. To create life is to weave from the web, and to die is to be woven back into the web. The Weave is also the force that keeps the planes together. Magic, both divine and arcane, uses the Weave.
She is the patron to many doctors and sometimes clerics and priests.

deity.name: Carnage
deity.title: the Bloodfather
deity.symbol: An open mouth with sharp teeth
entries: Carnage is well known for his destruction and manipulation of the Weave to cause more massive destruction. Not even Umbrava, who brought him to divinity in the first place, was able to tolerate the destruction Carnage brought to the multiverse as he tore through the Weave. Fallen deities are either illegal or at least frowned upon, but Carnage is the most illegal deity to worship, in the same way as practising carnomancy.

deity.name: Chisiet
deity.title: the Dragon God
entries: The first dragon of Xhoria, Chisiet, was touched by Lumen. He became Chisiet, the Dragon God. He made the first dragonborn and dragons. His greed and lust for power made him attempt to beat the Burning Hand, to take control over light and dark. This failed miserably, causing him to fall from divinity and indirectly doom all his creations with him.

deity.name: Erudaine
deity.title: of the Other Worlds
entries: The Erudaine are not a single deity, but a group. They were powerful otherworldly entities that had strong unknown and unheard of powers. This intrigued Umbrava, who touched them, turning them into deities. The Erudaine used their newfound power to give others part of their power in return for favors. This displeased Umbrava, who felt that their divinity was misused. Umbrava cursed them, causing them to fall from divinity and be in a state of imprisonment. They still give out their power, even after becoming fallen deities.

deity.name: Zuriel
deity.title: the Second Twin
entries: Zuriel was the twin brother of Asteran, the First Twin. After both being touched by Lumen, they became lords over angels. Umbrava managed to corrupt Zuriel, causing him to become filled with greed. Zuriel wanted to have more than both of them combined and thus betrayed his brother Asteran. He wounded Asteran, but was not able to kill him. Lumen doomed Zuriel, causing him to fall from divinity and now live in the shadow of his brother.

variantrule.name: Large Mechanics
entries: These bullets are provided to place all the changes in their entirety in a single place of reference. Only a few of these will come up often, and those are fairly simple and memorable. The changes are as follows

items: The races have advantage on Strength ability checks and Strength saving throws. For this reason, these races are assumed to be strong, and do not need to gain a Strength score bonus—they will usually roll high anyway, except on attacks and damage.
The Large weapons deal an extra 1d4 damage.
Your normal unarmed strike damage is 2 + your Strength modifier.
The creature takes up a 10 by 10 foot area.

To fit into a Medium area, the creature must squeeze into the space costing double its movement, disadvantage on attack rolls and Dexterity saving throws, and attack rolls against it to have advantage.

The creature's push, drag, lift, and carrying capacity are all calculated for Large size. Push, drag, and lift are 60 times your Strength score while carrying capacity multiplies your Strength score by 30 unless otherwise noted. (This is overwritten by my homebrew rules for 
ameref{carry}. See that section for more info)
The races are able to grapple and shove Huge creatures.
If you attempt to handle something very small, such as a vial of acid, the DM may call for a Dexterity check where a smaller sized creature would automatically succeed.
You require mounts at least one size larger than you as normal.

You require four times as much food as normal and your armor requires four times the materials to be made. It is about that much more expensive, and that's assuming you can find it. Based on how common these races are in your world, they might be found in populous cities. You also require larger shields, which are more common, but give no bonus to AC outside the norm.
All of these races still count as humanoids unless otherwise noted.
If you are proficient in any weapon, you are considered proficient for its Large sized version as well.
The Large versions of weapons are not very common. They cost at least twice that of a normal weapon. You may start with a single Large-sized weapon.

entries.name: Age
entries: Coatl in Xhoria reach adulthood at around the age of 50 and can live to be 1500 years old.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Coatl live in hierarchies, and are usually Lawful in nature.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Being creatures of the dark jungle or forest, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Size
entries: Depending on their subrace, coatl range from under 5 to over 8 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Draconic.

entries.name: Craftsmen
entries: You gain proficiency with an artisan's tools of your choice.

entries.name: Skillful
entries: You gain proficiency with one of the following skills of your choice: {@skillAcrobatics}, {@skillStealth}, {@skillSurvival}, or {@skillNature}.

entries.name: Amphibian Lizards
entries: You have a swimming speed of 30 feet, and you can breathe air and water.

entries.name: Bite
entries: Your fanged maw is a natural weapon, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with it, you deal piercing damage equal to 1d6 + your Strength modifier, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

entries.name: Savage Attacks
entries: When you score a critical hit with a melee weapon attack, you can roll one of the weapon's damage dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage of the critical hit.

entries.name: Hungry Jaws
entries: As a bonus action, you can make a special attack with your bite. If the attack hits, it deals its normal damage, and you gain temporary hit points equal to your Constitution modifier (minimum of 1), and you can't use this trait again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Lizard Weapon Training
entries: You are trained for combat. You have proficiency with the longsword, shortsword, mace, and warhammer.

entries.name: Large Coatl
entries: You are a large creature, see the rules about large creatures here: {@variantrule Large Mechanics|EGtX}

Amid the darkness and horror of a world splintering apart, the armies of the true creators, we who were ancient at the dawn of time, will march forth once more. We shall sweep away all that is chaos and disorder, for ours is the true path, and none shall defy us.
entries.by: Translation from ancient plaques atributed to Venerable Lord Kroak.

entries: This race was {@i heavily} influenced by the Lizardmen from the Warhammer Fantasy and replaces the {@race Lizardfolk|VGM} from {@i Volo's Guide to Monsters.}

The society of the Lizardmen is highly sophisticated and ancient beyond reckoning. It was they who first became the world's first true civilizations, erecting their cities of ancient stone long before the rise of men, elf or dwarf. It was they who were writing down ancient mathematics and astronomy upon chiseled tablets of stone long before mortals even learned how to write.

entries.name: Spawning Pools
entries: The coatl's core species such as the zotl, nagua and kroxelhua are not born from eggs, like their feral reptilian cousins, but are birth from special pools and ponds located within sacred regions of jungle. This birthing of a new generation of coatl are called Spawnings. Every Temple-City has its own sacred ponds and expanses of marsh where these spawning events occur. Zotl and kroxelhua tend to spawn in ponds and swamps open to the sky, whereas nagua and certain other kroxelhua are usually spawned in dank subterranean caverns. Pyramid Temples are frequently built over the top of the entrances to such caverns and outlying swamps are sometimes made into rectangular ponds encircled by stone.

entries.name: Age
entries: Skavarot have an expected lifespan of about a handful of years or less; that said, were it not for the (often violent) internal competition of their species, they might live to be in their 20's. More powerful members of skavarot society tend to live longer, even hundreds of years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Skavarot are mostly built on chaos, but some gifted skavarot are good at complex mathematics and engineering, bending them a bit more to the lawful side. Their alignment is usually Chaotic or Neutral.

entries.name: Size
entries: Skavarot are large bipedal rats, they are between 4 and 5 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Superior Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to the depths of caverns and caves, including the Underdark, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 120 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Skavarot Resilience
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Undercommon.

entries.name: Agressive
entries: As a bonus action, you can move up to your movement speed toward a hostile creature you can see or hear. You must end this move closer to the enemy than you started.

entries.name: Skavarot Weapon Training
entries: You are trained for combat. You have proficiency with the shortsword, scimitar, hand crossbow and heavy crossbow.

entries.name: Artificer's Lore
entries: Whenever you make an Intelligence ({@skill History}) check related to magic items, alchemical objects, or technological devices, you can add twice your proficiency bonus, instead of any proficiency bonus you normally apply.

entries.name: Arcane Knowledge
entries: You have proficiency in the Arcana skill.

entries.name: Extra Language
entries: You can speak, read, and write one extra language of your choosing.

All decent folk find the common rat repulsive. Harbinger of disease, it scavenges on our waste-heaps and frightens our children. How immeasurably worse then is the foul Skaven - standing on its hindlegs in foul parody of a human. Rats as tall as man, and blessed with the most vile intellect and cunning. They are the dark side of our souls, come to destroy us for our sins.
entries.by: Anton of King's Glade, Burned at the stake, AS 10643 for pernicious declamation.

entries: This race was {@i heavily} influenced by the Skaven from the Warhammer Fantasy.

The skavarot race often represents all the things that the typical good-natured citizenry of the Empire despise. As a whole, the skavarot is, at its base, a very selfish and unloving creature, raised within a turbulent society that only promotes violence, cunning, and the need for survival. As such, each and every skavarot has a mindset that is singularly focused on survival, which offers little room for remorse or pity, not even for close "friends" or even siblings or kin. Not only are the skavarot a petty and jealous race, they are also devious and sly in their attitude to one another.

entries.name: Engineering Geniuses
entries: Although their tinkering can be compared to that of gnomes, they disregard safety entirely. They make impressive contraptions and are very inventive, but their inventions are as dangerous to others as they are to themselves. Some inventions the skavarot have made are replacement arms, legs, or an eye, and large energy weapons such as cannons or artillery.

entries.name: Cautious Rodents
entries: To a skavarot, life is a complex web of plots and intrigues designed by his enemies for the sole purpose of harming him and him only. A cautious skavarot, however, never attracts more attention than is necessary, for fear of becoming a tempting target for an upstart underling or a suspicious superior. It is common for skavarot to show their superiority towards their underlings by showering them with shrill abuse on a regular basis. These actions are as much as to inflate a skavarot's ego as to deter potential rivals. Thus, while the failures of a skavarot are due to the weaknesses or the machinations of others, their achievements are nevertheless the result of his own incredible talents. To a skavarot, if a group assault decimates the enemy, it would be thanks to his brilliant planning. If a skavarot horde emerges in the right place, it is thanks to his genius that they have discovered the right path. Whether it's the right time, the right place, or the perfect weather, a skavarot would always believe that he is a master of strategy, logistics and politics beyond anyone else in the entire Under-Empire.

entries.name: Age
entries: Telorin age in a similar way as elves, but live shorter lives. A telorin can live to be 500 years old.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Telorin value prestige and respect, so they lean strongly towards lawful.

entries.name: Size
entries: Telorin range from under 5 to over 6 feet tall, but their antlers can easily make them over 6 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being charmed, and magic can't put you to sleep.

entries.name: Gift of Auberon
entries: You know the {@spell druidcraft} cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell hunter's mark} spell; you must finish a long rest in order to cast the spell again using this trait. Once you reach 5th level, you can also cast the {@spell aid} spell; you must finish a long rest in order to cast the spell again using this trait. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Sylvan.

entries.name: Dune's Endurance
entries: You can focus yourself to occasionally shrug off injury. When you take damage, you can use your reaction to roll a d12. Add your Constitution modifier to the number rolled, and reduce the damage by that total. After you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Powerful Build
entries: You count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.

entries.name: Cold Born
entries: You have resistance to cold damage.

entries.name: Extra Language
entries: You can speak, read, and write one extra language of your choice.

entries.name: Healing Warmth
entries: As an action, you can touch a creature and cause it to regain a number of hit points equal to your level. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Keen Senses
entries: You have proficiency in the Perception skill.

entries.name: Telorin Armor Training
entries: You have proficiency in light and medium armor.

entries.name: Midland Weapon Training
entries: You have proficiency with the light crossbow, shortbow, hand crossbow, heavy crossbow, and longbow.

entries.name: Rivals of the Large
entries: When you damage a creature with an attack or a spell and the creature's size is larger than yours, you can cause the attack or spell to deal extra damage to the creature. The extra damage equals your level. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.
This race was inspired by some concept art for the web series Starfall.
Telorin are a deer-like elf race that populate Xhoria. Most of them come from either the deserts and plains of Adoya and Belora, or the cold climates of the north and south of Xhoria.

entries.name: Fey Descendants
entries: Telorin are descendants of the old fey elves, but became their own thing under the influence of Auberon, their main deity. Their fey heritage can be clearly seen in their appearance. Telorin have antlers that take any of a variety of shapes - most midland telorin have short but long antlers like those of deer, but can also have very large antlers like those of elk. Frost telorin have wide and thick antlers like those of reindeer and moose. Desert telorin have antlers that look more like those of gazelles and buffalo. They have ears like those of deer and just above the nose is a bit of fur.

entries.name: Giant Rivalry
entries: Telorin's rivalry with giants and goliaths goes way back in history. Especially the midland telorin have had competition with local giant or goliath communities. Nowadays they are not hostile to each other, but ancient conflicts still influence the telorin's decisions when encountering giants or goliaths.

entries.name: Age
entries: The age of any goliath is an unpredictable variable. Due to the harsh climate and general danger, goliaths over 100 are rare, but it is conceivable a sustained goliath could live for a handful of centuries. They enter real adulthood intheir late twenties, but are often considered mature mentally by their earlier twenties.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: The goliath society with its defined duty and roles has a pure lawful bent, over anything else. Neutral is the most common, but good, neutral, or evil, the law is more important to any goliath than their altruism or lack thereof.

entries.name: Size
entries: Goliaths are between 11 and 14 feet tall and weigh between 1000 and 1400 pounds. Your size is Large.

entries.name: Mountain Born
entries: You're acclimated to high altitude, including elevations above 20,000 feet. You're also naturally adapted to cold climates, as described in chapter 5 of the Dungeon Master's Guide.

entries.name: Jörmungandr
entries: You count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift, in addition to grappling and shoving.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Giant.

entries.name: Spark of War
entries: You have proficiency in the Intimidation skill.

entries.name: Forges of Old
entries: Whenever you make an Intelligence ({@skill History}) check related to the origin of forged weaponry or armor, you can add twice your proficiency bonus, instead of any proficiency bonus you normally apply.

entries.name: Ghost of the Anvil
entries: You gain proficiency in smith's tools. This was not taught to you, but came innately as a child, as it comes to all cinder goliaths, like all children knowing how to breathe.

entries.name: Might of Skadi
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Deception} or the {@skill Survival} skill.

entries.name: Cloak of Winter
entries: You have resistance to cold damage.

Once, the Elder Giants walked upon the earth and blessed it. They climbed mountains in passing, and waded kraken filled seas in their baths. Once. These legends circle and grow around mountain fires, on snow-streaked ridges and barren arctic wastelands, fires that warm the chilled skin of a people who are but a shell of their ancestors: the giants, who now weep and shiver in their graves and halls. These people are all that are left of the great striders of the world.

entries.name: Robust and Fair
entries: The small, minimal subsistence tribes that hike the cliffs and spines are challenged eternally for food, water, shelter, and life. There is no room for failure among a tribe such as this, and each accomplishment raises the bar for every other goliath in the tribe.

These people candidly place weight on individual skill and duty to the tribe. Defeat is sometimes inevitable, and is used as a tool for future victories; however, when victories are tallied by the fortunate, defeats always outlive such defeasible goliaths.

entries.name: Open Law
entries: The most successful tribal leaders are those who can show their strength and endurance, as well as use it. The idea of a bloodline of rulers is utterly alien to them, because the person with the most perseverance and might should always rule. This ideal often comes into conflict with any kind of government that doesn't suit this type.

entries.name: Cold and Cinder
entries: Two descendent lines of the almighty giants remain standing in the face of the world, that of fire, and those of ice. Some tribes are mono-typical, while others include both kinds due to the rare joining of tribes. Regardless of the history, every member of the tribe is expected to give not their best, but the best of the majority of the tribe. This includes the old, sick, and injured. Any such goliath usually dies in an attempt to keep up, or quietly slips away in a storm to perish.

entries.name: An Extinguishing Pride
entries: All goliaths have a sense of pride from their giant heritage, but both they and this pride are dwindling by the day. The ordning is no more than a faint word in a gallant chant that means something or other official. The goliaths are dying, and they know it: for the last hundreds of years, the amount of tribes has declined, to the point where only ice and fire are left. The thought that perhaps these, too, will leave the world through death and failure is a marking of maturity.

entries.name: Goliath Names
entries: Remnants of a culture long dead still grip the hearts and minds of the goliaths today, including their naming system: a birth name assigned by a parent, a nickname assigned by the tribal chief, and a family or clan name. A birth name is up to three syllables long, a nickname is usually a combination of two words, and clan names range from three to eight syllables.

Birth names are usually linked to initial appearance or prior experience of the parentage, but a gender link is rare, as goliaths see equality, and no one has a right to any name before they prove themselves, and no kind of name is better than any other.
A nickname can and usually is revised by the goliath's latest great deed, whether it be good or ill. Goliaths assign nicknames to other races, and use them in common speech to refer to individuals.
All three names are usually presented with an introduction, because any individual is the sum of who they were born from, who they were born as, and who they have become.

items.name: Birth Names:
items.entry: Aglo, Aukan, Akeldama, Eklath, Gael, Graeel, Ilikan, Jontar, Jonvagus, Keori, Kuorruk, Manneo, Nalla, Orag, Orilo, Paavu, Pethani, Thalai, Thotham, Trogdor, Uthal, Uther, Vaegar, Vimak

items.name: Nicknames:
items.entry: Bearslayer, Dawncaller, Dragonsbane, Fearless, Flintseer, Hornhunter, Lonehunter, Mofu, Skywatcher, Swordmeow, Threadtwister, Twice-Orphaned, Twisted-Torc, Wordpainter, Wrathless

items.name: Clan Names:
items.entry: Anakalathai, Elanithino, Gathakanathi, Gorthallanka, Kalagiano, Katholavi, Kolaigileana, Moonsnow, Ogolakanu, Thuliaga, Thunukalathi, Thjornada, Vaimelaga, Vyvenskia

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The Amaranth Syndicate medallion, a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 15 gp

entries.name: Feature: Ear to the Ground
entries: You are in frequent contact with the Amaranth Syndicate. These people can be found all around Adoya, but mostly in the larger cities. This connection comes in the form of a contact in any city you visit, a person who provides information about the people and places of the local area.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Use the tables for the {@background Criminal} background in the Player's Handbook as the basis for your bounty hunter's traits and motivations, modifying the entries when appropriate to suit your identity as a bounty hunter.

For instance, your bond might involve other bounty hunters or the individuals that employ you. Your ideal could be associated with your determination always to catch your quarry or your desire to maintain your reputation for being dependable.
You are a known member of the Amaranth Syndicate, the faction of bounty hunters. You have already completed many bounties and have recently earned a promotion to become a Prowler.

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The Golden Order token, a set of {@item fine clothes|phb}, and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 25 gp

entries.name: Feature: Leverage
entries: You can exert leverage over one or more individuals below you in the guild's hierarchy and demand their help as needs warrant. For example, you can have a message carried across a neighborhood, procure a short carriage ride without paying, or have others clean up a bloody mess you left in an alley. The DM decides if your demands are reasonable and if there are subordinates available to fulfill them. As your status in the guild improves, you gain influence over more people, including ones in greater positions of power.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Members of the Golden Order range from the decadent nobility at the top of the oligarchy to the debt-ridden wretches at the bottom. You fall somewhere between those extremes, so you might behave with the arrogance of the very rich or the humility of the impoverished.

entries.caption: Personality Traits
rows: I am always willing to act in accordance with the financial incentive offered.
Debts are never meant to be forgiven.
I am accustomed to enjoying the finest pleasures money can buy.
No one could doubt that I am a cut above the masses of pitiful peasants that infest the city.
I can't stand to spend a zib more than necessary to purchase what I need.
I hate it when people try to make light of a serious situation.
I want to make sure everyone is aware of how wealthy, powerful, and important I am.
I can't think of anything to look forward to.

entries.caption: Ideals
rows: {@b Guild}. My guild is all that really matters. (Any)
{@b Wealth}. I will do whatever it takes to become as rich as the oligarchs. (Evil)
{@b Power}. One day, I will be the one giving orders. (Evil)
{@b Prestige}. I want to be admired, respected, feared, or even hated for my position and wealth. (Evil)
{@b Stability}. The economy functions best when chaos is kept under control and everyone knows their place. (Lawful)
{@b Eternity}. I want to live forever\u2014in the flesh as long as possible, and as a spirit afterward. (Any)

entries.caption: Bonds
rows: The unbearable weight of my debt has driven me to desperation.
I'm duty-bound to obey the dictates of an ancestor  Order.
I value my worldly goods more highly than my mortal life.
An oligarch publicly humiliated me, and I will exact revenge on that whole family.
My faith in the Order never wavers.
I want to prove myself more worthy than an older sibling and thereby ensure that I inherit a greater share of my parents' wealth.

entries.caption: Flaws
rows: I hold a scandalous secret that could ruin my family forever\u2014but could also earn me the favor of The Golden Eagle.
I'm convinced that everyone I know is plotting against me.
I'll brave any risk if the monetary reward is great enough.
I am convinced that I am far more important than anyone else is willing to acknowledge.
I have little respect for anyone who isn't wealthy.
I'll take any opportunity to steal from wealthier people, even for worthless trinkets.

entries: You are a member of the Golden Order and have been profiting off of your wares or services, or you have been persuading key members of the government to allow you more freedom in getting the money you deserve. You have been recently promoted to a Crow of the Order.

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The Jesters emblem, a crimson colored mask, a {@item Disguise Kit|phb}, a set of dark {@item common clothes|phb} including a hood, and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 10 gp.

entries.name: Feature: A Favor in Turn
entries: You have gained enough clout within the Jesters that you can call in a favor from your contacts, should you be close enough to a center of Jester activity. A request for a favor can be no longer than 20 words, and is passed up the chain to an undisclosed higher-up for approval. This favor can take a shape up to the DM's discretion depending on the request, with varying speeds of fulfillment: If muscle is requested, an NPC Jester minion can temporarily aid the party. If money is needed, a small loan can be provided. If you've been imprisoned, they can look into breaking you free, or paying off the jailer.

The turn comes when a favor is asked to be repaid. The favor debt can be called in without warning, and many times with intended immediacy. Perhaps the player is called to commit a specific burglary without the option to decline. Maybe they must press a dignitary for a specific secret at an upcoming ball. The Jesters could even request a hit on an NPC, no questions asked or answered. The DM is to provide a debt call proportionate to the favor fulfilled. If a favor is not repaid within a reasonable period of time, membership to the Jesters can be revoked, and if the debt is large enough, the player may become the next hit contract to make the rounds.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Use the tables for the {@bacgkround Criminal} background in the PHB as the basis for your traits and motivations, modifying the entries when appropriate to suit your identity as a member of the Jesters. Your bond is likely associated with your fellow Jester members or the individual who introduced you to the organization. Your ideal probably involves establishing your importance and indispensability within the Jesters. You joined to improve your livelihood and sense of purpose.

You have been working your way up the chain of command within the Jesters. You might have deceived many or killed some important targets for the guild and have earned yourself a promotion to Living Shadow, gaining your first colored mask within the guild.

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: One set of {@item traveler's clothes|phb}, an omniral weapon (replacing one you start with), a trophy taken from a fallen enemy (a dagger, broken blade, or a piece of a fiend's horn), a {@item pouch|phb} containing 5 gp.

entries.name: Feature: Omniral and Douzen Communication
entries: As a member of one of the Douzen Clans you have access to their communication network within Xhoria. The clans have an intricate network of trained birds that are used to deliver messages, missions, and return reports back to the clan headquarters. This, together with divination, is the spine of the Douzen Clan communication network.

You also have your own omniral weapon, created from the magical ore from Valuren and a bit of your own blood, which grows with you the more evil you vanquish from Xhoria. Douzen Clan members will most always use their personal omniral weapon above any other magical weapon. Your weapon evolve according to the clan you belong to.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Use the tables for the soldier background in the Player's Handbook as the basis for your traits and motivations, modifying the entries when appropriate to suit your identity as a member of one of the Douzen Clans.

For instance, your bond might involve other clan members or the individuals that employ you. Your ideal could be associated with your determination always to defeat evil and become better at the art of the blade.

You have been accepted into one of the three Douzen Clans. You are either member of the Clan of the Fierce Monkey, Clan of the Thunderdrake, or Clan of the Tide. You have the rank of Novice within the clan.

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: Tattered robes, a symbol of your dark lord, a blasphemous holy text, a curved ritual {@item dagger|phb}, a {@item poisoner's kit|phb}, and a small {@item pouch|phb} containing 5 gp.

entries.name: Feature: Secret Signs
entries: You know the secret symbology of your cult, which can pop up in some surprising places. Some nobles, influential persons, or even common townsfolk may also be members of your cult, and with a subtle gesture or knowing handshake you can discern who still follows the ways of your dark lord.

Cloisters of your cult may also be hidden across the land, identified by the secret signs and symbols designed to lead the faithful to places of dark worship. Such cloisters often con- tain enough lodging and food for at least ten people, for a week, and sometimes harbor eldritch treasures belonging to the cult. Cloisters with treasure still intact likely contain practicing cultists or guardian monsters, however; your cult was not foolish enough to let its secrets remain unguarded.

entries.caption: Personality Traits
rows: Everything is a sign of coming doom. Every. Single. Thing.
The world outside is so exciting! Now I can do everything the dark lord used to forbid, like drinking wine, or wearing shoes!
The dark lord used to order us to do everything. It’s a little hard for me to live without that.
if my friends will let me, I'll openly reminisce about my old days in the cult all day long.
I still can’t help but check the holy scriptures for advice about any given situation.
It’s no big deal, it’s not the end of the world. That’s not for another five years, three months, ten days, twelve hours...
It's still important to leave the old offerings, to perform the old rites.
I'll happily inform those I meet of the many ways in which they are being heretical.

entries.caption: Ideals
rows: {@b Loyalty}. My new companions are my new family, I will protect them. (Lawful)
{@b Reparation}. I must fix the evils my cult has done. (Good)
{@b InLoyalty}. My new companions are my new family, I will protect them. (Lawful)
{@b Reparation}. I must fix the evils my cult has done. (Good)
{@b Independence}. I'll never be bound in servitude again! (Chaotic)
{@b Power}. The dark lord was weak in the end. I will be stronger than they ever were. (Evil)
{@b Secrets}. The lore of my cult is historic- ally important, and I should preserve it. (Neutral)
{@b Revision}. The cult failed because the holy book was wrong. I must learn about the outside world, and fix the book’s errors. (Neutral)

entries.caption: Bonds
rows: I must discover the truth behind my dark lord, even if it kills me.
I need to reconnect with the people from my life before the cult, if I can ever find them.
I must free other minions from un- witting service to dark masters.
A monstrous, immortal guardian of the cult is hunting me. I pray it never finds me.
I sold my soul in service to the dark lord, and now I seek to reclaim it.
The day of reckoning is coming, and my knowledge is the key to stopping it.

entries.caption: Flaws
rows: If I ever had the chance, I'd definitely rejoin my cult.
I’m a little too into blood sacrifice.
Knowledge is more important than sanity.
I'm often more interested in than frightened of abominable eldritch monsters.
I'm almost too willing to follow orders without thinking.
Murder was significantly less frowned upon by the cult than in the outside world.

entries: Once, perhaps not too terribly long ago, you served alongside your fellow neophytes. You worshipped at altars to a dark creature or eldritch god. performed the sacraments and blood sacrifices and adorned yourself with the proper tattoos or ceremonial scars. For a while. you basked in this dark glory with your fellows, feeling the camaraderie and clarity of purpose that comes with service to a higher, malign power.

But, something changed. Now, you wander the world outside of your isolated circle of brethren, either unwillingly or of your own volition. Surviving in the outside is difficult and often confusing after living as you did for so long, but perhaps a new circle of comrades could be of some assistance...

entries.name: Change of Heart
entries: Why did you walk away from the world you knew, and why did you seek something different? Was this a choice you made, or did fate separate you from your fellow devotees? Do you wish to undo the evil that your cult perpetuated, or would you rejoin your cult if given the chance?
Work with your DM to decide what you and your cult worshipped, how much of your cult still exists. You may also need to work out why you left the cult, which you can roll on the following table.

entries.caption: Change of Heart
rows: I witnessed a particularly gruesome rite and ran for my life.
A botched ritual slaughtered the other members of my circle. Only I survived.
I asked the wrong kind of questions. The others planned to sacrifice me to our dark lord, but I escaped.
Adventurers hunted us down, and only I was able to escape.
The other cultists disappeared through a portal to a land of unspeakable horrors. Terrified, I stayed behind.
The others took their own lives to ascend. I could not.
I no longer believed in what we were doing. It seemed wrong, somehow.
A friend or family member rescued me, taking me away by force.

spell.name: Radiant Ray
entries: A burst of radiant energy comes forth from your hands forming a line 100 feet long and 5 feet wide and blasts out from you in a direction you choose. Each creature in the line must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 4d10} radiant damage, and it is {@condition blinded} for 1 minute. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition blinded}. A {@condition blinded} creature can make a Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by {@scaledamage 4d10|3-9|1d10} for each slot level above 3rd.
